fields.headline: Photographer Jane Bown's best shot
fields.bodyText: I like this picture because I'd been pretty smart. It was in 1979 and the Observer office was tucked away in Blackfriars, not too far from the Old Bailey. The Jeremy Thorpe trial was just finishing and I said: "Does anyone want a photograph of Jeremy Thorpe?" Someone said: "Oh no, we're not interested." But I thought: "I'm jolly well going." It wasn't very far away. The reason I like the shot so much is more down to the circumstances under which it was taken. The whole trial had been such a strange affair [Thorpe, the former leader of the Liberal party, was acquitted of attempted murder and conspiracy]. There were crowds of people waiting for him outside. We didn't know whether he would come out or not, or whether he was going to try for a secret getaway. So when he did come out, everyone went mad. We had been told beforehand that he would make a speech, that he would talk to reporters in four different places in turn. That way the photographers would all be able to get a shot. But I knew that wasn't going to happen – it never does. Everyone would just pounce. So I got low down, because that's what I always do. I'm short – five foot and half an inch – and photographers are always pushing me down when I get in their way. I was half-kneeling when I noticed a whole column of policemen forming outside the Old Bailey. I realised they were making a little path and I thought: I bet he's coming down that path, which indeed he did. That's how I got the picture. No one else had spotted it, so I was able to get into a good position. The other pictures all show him surrounded by reporters. This was the only one of him on his own. I'm quite wily, you see, I like outsmarting the others. I've never thought of myself as a portrait photographer. I suppose I am, by definition, but I like the rough and tumble, getting in there first. CV Born: Dorset, 1925. Has been taking photographs for the Observer since 1949. Studied: "Guildford School of Art. It was the first photographic school after the war." Inspiration: "I never took much interest in photography when I was younger. Does that sound awful?" High point: "Nothing really. I'm hopeless. I'm always short on words." Top tip: "Keep looking. That's all I did. Kept my eyes open."
